questions.question_text: Are said to exhibit physical data independence if they do not depend on the physical schema.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report that will list only the column DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, and PRICE of all PART whose CLASS is equal to HW.

SELECT DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE class="HW";

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column PARTNUM, DESCRIPTION and PRICE of all PARTS where price is less than 500. Sort the PRICE in ascending order.

choices.text: SELECT PARTNUN, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE < 500;
SELECT PARTNUN, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE > 500;
SELECT PARTNUN, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE <=500;
SELECT PARTNUN, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE >= 500;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS and PRICE of all parts where the description fourth letter starting from the first is equal to ‘D’.

choices.text: SELECT DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, PRICES FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘___D%’;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, PRICES FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘%D___’;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, PRICES FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘D%’;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PARTNUM, CLASS, PRICES FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘%D’;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column DESCRIPTION, CLASS and PRICE of all PARTS where class is not equal to AP.

choices.text: SELECT DESCRIPTION, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE CLASS NOT LIKE ‘%AP%’;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE CLASS NOT LIKE ‘%AP’;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE CLASS != AP;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE CLASS <> AP;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column CLASS, DESCRIPTION and PRICE of all PARTS where price range is between 200 to 500. Sort the Price in descending order.

choices.text: SELECT CLASS, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE BETWEEN 200 AND 500;
SELECT CLASS, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE BETWEEN 500 AND 500;
SELECT CLASS, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE BETWEEN =200 AND 500;
SELECT CLASS, DESCRIPTION, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE PRICE BETWEEN 200 AND BETWEEN 500;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column DESCRIPTION, ONHAND and WAREHOUSE of all PARTS where ONHAND is greater than or equal to 21.

choices.text: SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, WAREHOUSE FROM PARTS WHERE ONHAND >=21;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, WAREHOUSE FROM PARTS WHERE ONHAND <=21;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, WAREHOUSE FROM PARTS WHERE ONHAND =21;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, WAREHOUSE FROM PARTS WHERE ONHAND >21;

choices.text: SELECT * FROM PARTS ORDER BY DESCRIPTION DESC;

SELECT * FROM PARTS ORDER BY DESC;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column DESCRIPTION, WAREHOUSE, CLASS and PRICE of all parts where the description contains keyword ‘SHE’.

SELECT DESCRIPTION, WAREHOUSE, CLASS, PRICE FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘%SHE’;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report that will merge the column DESCRIPTION and PRICE put a literal character string of = “ with a price of ” in between the two columns. Limit the rows returned by getting only the partnum that starts with letter ‘K’

choices.text: SELECT (DESCRIPTION|| ‘WITH A PRICE OF’ || PRICE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM LIKE ‘K%’;
SELECT (DESCRIPTION|| ‘WITH A PRICE OF’ || PRICE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM LIKE ‘%K’;
SELECT (DESCRIPTION|| ‘WITH A PRICE OF’ || PRICE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM LIKE ‘%K%’;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report that will display the DESCRIPTION, WAREHOUSE AND distinct value for CLASS.

SELECT DESCRIPTION, WAREHOUSE, CLASS FROM PARTS;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing the column PARTNO, DESCRIPTION and WAREHOUSE. Get only that description that does not ends with ‘ER’. Note that you have to merge the said three columns, rename the merge column as “Parts Record”. Below is the sample output for column. Parts Record AT94is the part number ofIRONwhich belong to warehouse3

choices.text: SELECT (PARTNUM || ‘is the part number of’|| DESCRIPTION || ‘which belongs to’ || WAREHOUSE FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM NOT LIKE ‘%ER’;
SELECT (PARTNUM || ‘is the part number of’ ||DESCRIPTION || ‘which belongs to’ || WAREHOUSE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM NOT LIKE ‘ER%’;
SELECT (PARTNUM ‘is the part number of’ DESCRIPTION‘which belongs to’WAREHOUSE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM NOT LIKE ‘%ER’;
SELECT (PARTNUM || ‘is the part number of’ ||DESCRIPTION || ‘which belongs to’ || WAREHOUSE) FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM LIKE ‘%ER’;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column PARTNUM, CLASS and ONHAND of all parts where partnum is equal to AT94, DR93 and KV29. (Note 1 query only and do not use logical condition)

choices.text: SELECT PARTNUM, CLASS, ONHAND FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM IN (‘AT94’,’DR93’,’KV29’);
SELECT PARTNUM, CLASS, ONHAND FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM IN (AT94,DR93,KV29);
SELECT PARTNUM, CLASS, ONHAND FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM = (‘AT94’,’DR93’,’KV29’);
SELECT PARTNUM, CLASS, ONHAND FROM PARTS WHERE PARTNUM NOT IN (‘AT94’,’DR93’,’KV29’);

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing only the column DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, CLASS and PRICE of all price where the description ends with letter ‘N’.

choices.text: SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, CLASSS FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘%N’;

SELECT DESCRIPTION, ONHAND, CLASSS FROM PARTS WHERE DESCRIPTION LIKE ‘%N%’;

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct report listing the DESCRIPTION and Price (Note that in column PRICE add ADDITIONAL 10000). Get only the prices with no digit that is equal to ‘5’. Note that you have to concatenate the said column and rename the merge column as “New Price Lists”. Sort the data in DESC order by Price.

choices.text: SELECT DESCRIPTION, PRICE + 10000 AS “NEW PRICE LISTS” FROM PARTS ORDER BY PRICE DESC;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PRICE + 10000 AS NEW PRICE LISTS FROM PARTS ORDER BY PRICE DESC
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PRICE + 10000 AS “NEW PRICE LISTS” FROM PARTS ORDER BY PRICE;
SELECT DESCRIPTION, PRICE + 10000 + PRICE AS “NEW PRICE LISTS” FROM PARTS ORDER BY PRICE DESC;

questions.question_text: Choose the letter of the correct answer based on the table EMPLOYEES as shown below. Table 1.0 EMPLOYEES
questions.question_subtext: Which of the following is the correct query that display the maximum lastname concatenated to firstname and rename the column as “Employees Name”, Job_id and apply the ff. functions:
questions.question_note: • Count the Job_id; Apply where condition whose lastname ends with letter ‘N’; Group the job_id; and Apply having clause of employees having average salary that is greater than 10000.

choices.text: SELECT MAX(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS EMPLOYEES NAME, JOB_ID, COUNT(JOB_ID) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE LASTNAME LIKE '%N' GROUP BY JOB_ID HAVING AVG(SALARY)>10000
SELECT MAX(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS "EMPLOYEES NAME", JOB_ID, COUNT(JOB_ID) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE LASTNAME LIKE '%N' GROUP BY JOB_ID HAVING AVG(SALARY)<10000;
SELECT MAX(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS "EMPLOYEES NAME", JOB_ID, COUNT(JOB_ID) FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID WHERE LASTNAME LIKE '%N' HAVING AVG(SALARY)>10000;
SELECT MAX(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS "EMPLOYEES NAME", JOB_ID, COUNT(JOB_ID) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE LASTNAME LIKE '%N' GROUP BY JOB_ID HAVING AVG(SALARY)>10000;

questions.question_text: Which of the following query is correct which will display the same output as shown below?

choices.text: SELECT MIN(initcap(FIRSTNAME||' surnname is '||LASTNAME)) AS "COMPLETE NAME", MIN(MANAGER_ID) AS "LOWEST MANAGER_ID" FROM EMPLOYEES;
SELECT MIN(LOWER(FIRSTNAME||' surnname is '||LASTNAME)) AS "COMPLETE NAME", MIN(MANAGER_ID) AS "LOWEST MANAGER_ID" FROM EMPLOYEES;
SELECT MIN(initcap(FIRSTNAME||' surnname is '||LASTNAME)) AS COMPLETE NAME, MIN(MANAGER_ID) AS "LOWEST MANAGER_ID" FROM EMPLOYEES;
SELECT MIN(LOWER(FIRSTNAME||surnname is ||LASTNAME)) AS "COMPLETE NAME", MIN(MANAGER_ID) AS "LOWEST MANAGER_ID" FROM EMPLOYEES;

questions.question_text: Which of the following query is correct which will display the same output as shown below?

choices.text: SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), JOB_ID, MAX(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID LIKE 'REP%' GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), JOB_ID, MAX(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID LIKE '%REP%';
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), JOB_ID, MAX(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID LIKE '%REP%' GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), MIN(JOB_ID), MAX(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID LIKE '%REP%' GROUP BY JOB_ID;

questions.question_subtext: Which of the following is the correct that display distinct job_id and the the total number per distinct (unique) job_id.

choices.text: SELECT DISTICT(JOB_ID), COUNT(JOB_ID) AS “TOTAL NUMBER OF JOB_ID” FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT DISTICT(JOB_ID), COUNT(JOB_ID) AS “TOTAL NUMBER OF JOB_ID” FROM EMPLOYEES;
SELECT DISTICT((JOB_ID), COUNT(JOB_ID)) AS “TOTAL NUMBER OF JOB_ID” FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;

questions.question_text: Which of the following query is correct which will display the same output as shown below?
Which of the following query is correct which will display the same output as shown below?

choices.text: SELECT MIN(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS NAME, DEPARTMENT_ID FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE DEPARTMENT_ID IN(90,50) HAVING MIN(DEPARTMENT_ID)<=90;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS NAME, DEPARTMENT_ID FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE DEPARTMENT_ID IN(90,50) GROUP BY DEPARTMENT_ID HAVING MIN(DEPARTMENT_ID)<=90;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS NAME, DEPARTMENT_ID FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY DEPARTMENT_ID WHERE DEPARTMENT_ID IN(90,50) HAVING MIN(DEPARTMENT_ID)<=90;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME||FIRSTNAME) AS NAME, DEPARTMENT_ID FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE DEPARTMENT_ID IN(90,50) GROUP BY DEPARTMENT_ID HAVING(DEPARTMENT_ID)<=90;

questions.question_subtext: Which of the following is the correct report that display the smallest (minimum) Surname.. and apply the ff. functions:
questions.question_note: • Get the average salary; Group the data per job_id; Get only job_id with a keyword “REP”; and Apply having clause, which the max salary per job_id is greater than 5000.

choices.text: SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), AVG(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID LIKE ‘%REP%’ GROUP BY JOB_ID HAVING MAX(SALARY)>500;
SELECT CONCAT(DEPARTMENT_ID,JOB_ID),MIN(SALARY), MAX(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), AVG(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID WHERE JOB_ID LIKE ‘%REP%’ HAVING MAX(SALARY)>500;
SELECT MIN(LASTNAME), AVG(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES WHERE JOB_ID NOT LIKE ‘%REP%’ GROUP BY JOB_ID HAVING MAX(SALARY)>500;

questions.question_subtext: Which of the following is the correct query that display the Job_id and add the ff: function:
questions.question_note: • Count the total number of job_id per distinct values; Compute for the summary of salary per job_id; and Compute for the average salary per job_id

choices.text: SELECT COUNT (DISTINCT(JOB_ID) AS “NO. OF JOB_ID”, SUM(SALARY) AS “TOTAL SALARY”, AVG(SALARY) AS “AVERAGE SALARY” FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT DISTINCT(JOB_ID), COUNT * (JOB_ID) AS “NO. OF JOB_ID”, SUM(SALARY) AS “TOTAL SALARY”, AVG(SALARY) AS “AVERAGE SALARY” FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT DISTINCT(JOB_ID), COUNT(JOB_ID) AS “NO. OF JOB_ID”, SUM(SALARY) AS “TOTAL SALARY”, AVG(SALARY) AS “AVERAGE SALARY” FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY JOB_ID;
SELECT DISTINCT(JOB_ID), COUNT(JOB_ID) AS “NO. OF JOB_ID”, SUM(SALARY) AS “TOTAL SALARY”, AVG(SALARY) AS “AVERAGE SALARY” FROM EMPLOYEES;

choices.text: SELECT MAX(FIRSTNAME), MANAGER_ID, COUNT(SALARY), AVG(SALARY) FROM EMPLOYEES GROUP BY MANAGER_ID WHERE SALARY BETWEEN 6000 AND 10000 HAVING MIN(SALARY) >= 5000;
